p: Several allied species had been shown to lower blood glucose level. The hydroethanolic extract of C. acutifolia leaves showed a high antihyperglycemic effect at dose levels 10 and 50 mg/kg. An anthraquinone, chrysophanol, was isolated from the leaves of C. acutifolia and showed mild antidiabetic properties in cell culture. Its activity was proposed to be mediated through affecting glucose transport and the tyrosine phosphorylation of the insulin receptor, improving insulin action or insulin-independent effects [ 129].
